newsitem.title: JAPAN: TIFFE Euroyen edge lower in quiet Tokyo trade.
newsitem.headline: TIFFE Euroyen edge lower in quiet Tokyo trade.

text.p: The benchmark three-month December euroyen futures contract edged lower by the end of Tokyo morning trade, pressured by weaker Japanese government bonds (JGBs) amid a dearth of fresh factors, traders said.

Many operators appear to holding to the sidelines ahead of the Group of Seven (G7) summit, due to start later today, as well as next week's Bank of Japan (BOJ) "tankan" survey and JGB auctions, one city bank trader said.
At midday, the December contract stood at 99.08, down 0.02 from Thursday, after moving narrowly from 99.06 to 99.08. Volume was an extremely light 8,961 contracts.
Volume in the March contract rose to 15,828, a signal that a benchmark shift may be approaching.
The benchmark is said to have officially shifted when volume in a forward contract exceeds that of the current benchmark for a second successive day of Tokyo trade.
Some traders said activity in connection with the March contract was mainly speculative, as operators grew frustrated by a lack of movement in December.
JGBs dipped on pressure from an overnight slide that saw the key September contract fall as low as 123.85, although it later recovered to end Tokyo morning trade at 123.90
"Moves in the euroyen market today seem to be mainly confined to book-squaring," one city bank trader said.
Little impact was detected from comments out of Denver from U.S. President Bill Clinton, who voiced concern to Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto about Japan's rising trade surplus.
U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky said the U.S. will not dictate to Japan on deregulation, but will negotiate.
"There's not much new in these statements, and as a result there has so far been little impact," the city bank trader said.
The Bank of Japan (BOJ) drained 100 billion yen from the market in the face of a net surplus of 200 billion yen, a slightly more generous move than was expected by the market.
Overnight call money was being traded at 0.50 percent before the operation but moved to 0.48-0.49 afterwards.

In the longer end of the money market, around 40 billion yen of three-month certificates of deposit (CDs) were issued at 0.60 percent and 40 billion yen of two-month CDs at 0.59 percent, unchanged from Thursday. In the interest rate swap (IRS) market, the three-year IRS rate was quoted at 1.52/1.56 percent against 1.51/1.55 percent on Thursday.
